newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Microsoft steps up Singapore piracy war.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft steps up Singapore piracy war.

text.p: Software giant Microsoft Corp boosted its efforts to defeat software piracy on Thursday, opening a store with a local partner in the heart of what is reputed to be the home of pirated software in Singapore.
Microsoft said its partnership with Advance Gravis Computer Technology Pte Ltd would deter piracy by giving customers the confidence to buy genuine products with all the back-up benefits.
The company is not normally in the retail store business.

About 58 percent of software used in Singapore in 1994 was pirated, according to the Business Software Alliance, which represents leading software publishers. This accounted for US$45 million in lost revenue.
Within Asia, Singapore is now on par with Japan for having the lowest software piracy rates, said Paul Lovell, managing director of Microsoft, Singapore, at the opening of the store.
"I see trends (against piracy) within the Singapore government as very encouraging," he added.

The government has said it views software theft as a serious offence and local courts have been handing down heavier penalties. Retailers convicted of piracy have been fined as much as S$45,000 and jailed for up to 30 months.
